Strike Talks Drag On; Referendum Thursday
By ART LEVINE
Dean-elect George Benton called for a
Thursday recruiting referendum, while protesters went to Dr. Gordon's house last night to
question him on APL, governance and Brazil.
The move to Gordon's house followed an
active day of meetings, including an open convocation and discussions between Benton, the
strikers and Students for an Open University
(SOU), a pro-recruiting group. The newlyformed SOU disagrees with the Strike Committee mainly on the issue of banning recruiters.
The Strike Committee plans a meeting at
3 P.M. today to work on the referendum. The
SOU and strikers will also meet today with
Benton to discuss governance. The strikers met
with Benton yesterday morning and afternoon,
but they felt that he wasn't negotiating seriously with them.

Strikers, dissatisfied with the settlement last Thursday,
raise defiant fists to express their anger with the Administration.

At an informal meeting of the General
Assembly on Friday, -Benton asserted that he
had only agreed to discussions, not negotiations,
as part of the agreement last Thursday with the
strikers. Benton met yesterday morning with
10 representatives of the Strike Committee to
discuss governance and the recruiting referendum.
The Strike Committee presented new demands on Friday that asked the Administration
to: end classified research at APL by fiscal
1971, change the lab's priorities, set up a summer governance committee acceptable to the
strikers and Local 1231 and begin negotiations
on the weekend.
The Strike Com.mittee's latest move came
after growing dissatisfaction with the settlement
last rhursday, and a feeling among many protesters that they had been tricked by Dean-elect
George Benton.
The Thursday agreement suspended military recruiting from campus, unless a referendum that may be held by May 1 shows that
students want recruiters back. And, according
to the strikers, the Administration agreed to
continue serious negotiations on other issues
like governance and APL.
The meetings of the protesters since the
settlement have been marked by harsh attacks
on the administration.
At a Saturday meeting on the steps of
Shriver Hall, Jim Keogh remarked, "We didn't
understand how two-faced the .people we were
dealing with were. Let's not get fooled twice!"
Dr. Steve Pepper added to this by criticizing
members of the strikers' negotiating team for
being too weak.

team, was not as upset about the agreement as

some of the other strikers. "We may have fouled up," he said, "but with the strike force .still

The protesters met again Sunday, but they
left the decision on what action to take if negotiations fell through until yesterday at noon.
The activists want the summer governance
committee to consist of students acceptable to
them, and workers acceptable to Local 1231,
which represents Hopkins employees. Local
1231 came out for the strikers last Friday. The
Strike Committee also demands that the governance plan be presented to the entire university
community for approval on a one-man, one-vote
basis by Oct. 15, 1970.
In addition, the strikers feel that some of
the petitions which are circulating-are too broadly worded, and that if the referendum does take
place, it should require a "yes" vote to return
military recruiters.

Integrationists' Dilemma: Where to go From Here
By MARK REUTTER
School desegregation has reached
critical midpoint. In the past year the
Nixon Administration has blunted its
thrust, many blacks have rejected
integration and white opposition has made
it politically risky.
Some of the chief

The man who officially began it resides
on the forth floor of Gilman amid strewn
papers and an oversized bronze bust. He
is Dr. James Coleman, a hulking and
nearly bald sociologist, author of the controversial Coleman Report.
Completed in 1966, it framed the
answer of minority pupil achievement in
terms of school integration. Coleman,the
statistician, compiled literally hundreds
of figures to construct a diagram of an
intricate, self-sustainingweb of unequality.
Negro schools, he found, were inferior
to white schools in facilities, staff and
programs which, when combined with a
less motivated student body, produced
poor black performance on achievement
tests. And the black child's performance
would steadily worsen as he grew older.
Coleman saw bussing to achieve integration as the only solution to this rat
race.
Such advice Lyndon Johnson formally,

the dual school systems in the South. Government attorneys were taking their seats
in Southern courtrooms and placing their
support on the side of desegregation.
Things have changed since then. Nixon
has ended executive initiative in terminating Southern school segregation. No
longer do the Federal Courts of Florida
or the Carolinas witness government
and civil rights lawyers working in
unison; now Washington often sits on the
side of the local school boards.
***
Segregated schools are legally separated into two categories vastly different
in their origins. De jure segregation
denotes dual school systems that were
arbitrarily devised by local government.
The Supreme Court has called such systems unconstitutional. If the government
was the founder of dual black and white
schools, the Court has declared, then
the government must undo its actions.
On the other hand, in the North lies
de facto segregation. These schools are
predominately black or Jewish or Protestant, not because of a government
directive, but because social patterns

have caused such segregation to form.
The Supreme Court has not ruled on
this, although it has allowed local school
boards in the North to desegfegate voluntarily.
* * *

Nixon stated last month that he wants
to improve black schools instead of pushing for integration. According to Coleman's findings, such a decision is harmful.
Last Tuesday, speaking before the

average 20-25 per cent.
Paradoxically, though, Coleman is
now working with the Nixon Administration in HEW. He said that Nixon is neither

week. "Nixon's statement that he isn't
going to initiate a policy of bringing about
racial balance in segregated neighborhoods I think is unwise," Coleman noted,
"but his idea to place $1,5 billion to implement school •integration I think is
great."

Facts, however, may prove otherwise.
Nixon's $1.5 billion for "racially-impacted schools" is coming out of other

Times reported Sunday that it would probably come out of the Model Cities fund)
therefore lessening the all-around effect
Nixon's new program will make on the
poor.
Other education experts are also less
sure than Coleman that Nixon's school

all depends on how it's used," commented Dr. James McPartland of Social Relations. "This money will go down the
drain if it doesn't induce people to innovate new educational ideas." Dr. John
Walton of Education agreed. "Let's get
the money into the classroom, not other

Nixon has not specifically statedwhere

money will go to integrated summer
camps, boarding schools and after-school
activities.
**
Save the Neighborhood School has
been the cry of the Nixon Administration. It is a subtle delusion. 40 per cent
of all American pupils are now bused in
this country at their school board's
expense, not counting students who use
public transportation to get to school.
According to Dr. Robert Crane of
Social Relations, it is not the inconveniences of bussing that have caused
so much white opposition, it is that bussing is "the code word for intentional integration."
Crane's work has shown that integrated schools cut the black dropout rate in
half, and that blacks who attended integrated schools are more likely to associate with whites 15 years later.
However, such numerical figures can
be misleading. Crane's study is based
on Negroes in segregated and integrated
schools in the late 1940's and 1950's.
Dr. Walton noted that Crane had stereotyped blacks into one big, homogenous
pot.
"A black child who struggled in those
days to get into a white school cannot be
compared to an average ghetto student,"
Walton asserted. "That kid in the white
school probably came from a highly motivated family and is more likely to do better anywhere."
Walton places the importance of integrating schools far below his colleagues. "Bussing per se is not the
answer. It is one solution and possibly
not the most important one," Walton stated. "I would do some more experimentation instead of just bussing students

around."
There are several plans on how to more
creatively achieve integration. Pittsburg
has developed an educational park for its
high

schools have recently been installed outside Pittsburg's city limits. Both black
and white students are bussed to the
schools.
Another proposal calls for bussing students to another school only a few times

claim, would lessen the burden of daily

By JOHN A. ADAMS
Out of somewhat muddled strategic thinking and
smooth tactical maneuvering,a significant transfer
of power at Hopkins seems to have occurred.The
advent of mass radicalism on the Homewood Campus has, however, left many people confused.
There appears to be three major stresses emanating from last weeks actions-radical disagreement
with the military underpinnings of our culture, a
refusal to accept the current system of campus
governance and a slowly rising consciousness of
the class nature of our society. All of this is
emphatically underscored by the newly-constituted willingness of the mass of students to seize
power when the old system becomes obstructionist.
I need only to make brief allusions to the military behemoth that major segments of our population is growing to dislike. The need for change
Is apparent, but the incentive to change is not selfgenerating within the system. One is left with
two alternatives-pick up the gun and destroy the
system or move to create political pressure which
will force the system to make the radical changes
which are necessary.For the time being,the movement at Hopkins has chosen the latter, and I personally agree with that choice.
Given that the current situation must be altered,
the next step must be to ascertain the effectiveness
of various actions towards this end. First of all, if
a nation is to be democratic, the actions of a particular geographic segment is not, in itself, going
to drastically alter policy. However, these units
aggregated can command such power.

Recruiters Symbolic
This brings us to the recent moves to throw military recruiters off campus and the effects of
this action. In one sense, it is true that the
effect on military manpower is non-existent.
However, campus recruitment is an important
symbol.
Congressional action tying permission to recruit to appropriations for research and state-'
ments of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
about the effect on the military when a university
throws off recruiters attests to the symbolic importance of this action. Political power manipulations hinge largely on just such gestures. This
means of power transferral must not be underrated.
Students, especially undergraduates, have for a
long time felt as though they were second class
citizens. They watch the quality of their education
slide while a cumbersome, powerless maze of
committees flagellates itself. They quickly learn
that faculty members are promoted for their
research and that teaching success is virtually
ignored. Only when students have power and the
administration is relegated to its proper role of

servant, to students and faculty, will the problems that beset Hopkins be successfully attacked. An ever increasing number of students, including some even from the ranks of the cynics,
are coming to that realization.
The beginnings of a class consciousness is
evident in the demands of the strikers. A governance system to include workers, with all members of the community to be represented on a
one man-one vote basis, is truly classless. In
ever growing numbers, students are shaking off
the notion, inculcated in them by our society,
that a man who works with his hands is inferior
and not capable of directing those actions which
affect him. Workers declared their solidarity with
students and a class division began to disappear.

Faculty Assembly Denunciations
On the other hand, the Faculty Assembly of Friday sharpened another division. Faculty denunciations of legal if "extra-channel" political moves
as "terrorism" and "gangsterism," reveal the
reactionary sentiment of many members of the
faculty. Allusions to feudal privileges,("My office
is my castle") show their disdain for equality
for all members within this community.
The strike was a successful demonstration of
the classic theory that if the governed take communal action, they can relieve the rulers of their
power. As with the entire human community, a
redefinition of morals is presently taking place.
Our heritage of laws to protect the rights of
property against human rights is being discarded
in favor of the rights of people to be protected
from those who have the power of property. People are dropping the legal definition of Johns Hopkins Incorporated in favor of Johns Hopkins...a
body of scholars, both novice and experienced.
As with all struggles between systems, the logic
of one may not be valid when applied to the other.
People committed to the old may find little sense
in the arguments of the new. That is when the
struggle begins.
"Radical" denotes the amount of change
advocated. "Militant" denotes the means for
effecting that change. While both are associated
with violence, neither necessarily imply it. The
movement at Hopkins restrained its violent urges
and the administration chose to yield to the forces of change before violence had to be resorted
to. Let us all hope that this is a precedent which
will not be broken.

Time for Force
The lack of understanding that permeated the Faculty General Assembly meeting and the betrayed trust of
the Strike Negotiating Committee, which was promised
"negotiations" and delivered "discussions", indicates more
clearly than ever to us that to get anything done, students
must use force. As soon as the pressure is lifted, faculty
and administrators will simply and quite successfully turn
their backs.
Faculty and administrators are exploiting legitimate
divisions within the student body—most notably at the
moment on the open campus issue of recruiting. Let the
referendum settle the recruitment question. What we as
students must realize, however this issue is resolved, is
that we have more pervading common interests which
demand common action. The things this column has
spoken out on all year—governance, and classified research.
If we had had an adequate governance system, there would
have been no need for a strike at all.

that he sees no reason Hopkins students should be concerned with APL. His reasoning: It's too far away. It's

as parochial as all that.
We call upon the administration to quit stalling on
governance and for students to put down their books—
yes, only a week away from exams—and not be fooled a
second time.

Education vs. Governance
The Howard Committee on Governance had the good
sense to observe, "The primary problem (at Hopkins) is
the place and education of undergraduates in an institution
oriented to training in research." But it made the mistake
of separating the issues of governance and education.
All sorts of educational changes, from improved
course offerings to better teachers, are keyed to the amount of power students have. Yet the Howard group
has given in to faculty demands for rigid control over our
education: It created a separate committee, top-heavy
with administrators and faculty, to study undergraduate
'education. Also, the education committee has no timelimit set on its investigation. As with other committees

rather than promote it.

even less desire to improve our education. Only if they are
forced will they make significant changes. And the
best way we can make sure that happens is if undergraduates are given a vital role in educational policy-making.
Any new governance plan must include a way in
which undergraduates can help shape their own education.
The summer task force on governance must deal with
educational problems--and come up with a plan that gives
us real power. By trying to keep education and governance apart, the Howard Committee is trying to keep us
powerless.

By JOHN A. ADAMS
Out of somewhat muddled strategic thinking and
smooth tactical maneuvering,a significant transfer
of power at Hopkins seems to have occurred.The
advent of mass radicalism on the Homewood Campus has, however, left many people confused.
There appears to be three major stresses emanating from last weeks actions-radical disagreement
with the military underpinnings of our culture, a
refusal to accept the current system of campus
governance and a slowly rising consciousness of
the class nature of our society. All of this is
emphatically underscored by the newly-constituted willingness of the mass of students to seize
power when the old system becomes obstructionist.
I need only to make brief allusions to the military behemoth that major segments of our population is growing to dislike. The need for change
Is apparent, but the incentive to change is not selfgenerating within the system. One is left with
two alternatives-pick up the gun and destroy the
system or move to create political pressure which
will force the system to make the radical changes
which are necessary.For the time being,the movement at Hopkins has chosen the latter, and I personally agree with that choice.
Given that the current situation must be altered,
the next step must be to ascertain the effectiveness
of various actions towards this end. First of all, if
a nation is to be democratic, the actions of a particular geographic segment is not, in itself, going
to drastically alter policy. However, these units
aggregated can command such power.

Recruiters Symbolic
This brings us to the recent moves to throw military recruiters off campus and the effects of
this action. In one sense, it is true that the
effect on military manpower is non-existent.
However, campus recruitment is an important
symbol.
Congressional action tying permission to recruit to appropriations for research and state-'
ments of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
about the effect on the military when a university
throws off recruiters attests to the symbolic importance of this action. Political power manipulations hinge largely on just such gestures. This
means of power transferral must not be underrated.
Students, especially undergraduates, have for a
long time felt as though they were second class
citizens. They watch the quality of their education
slide while a cumbersome, powerless maze of
committees flagellates itself. They quickly learn
that faculty members are promoted for their
research and that teaching success is virtually
ignored. Only when students have power and the
administration is relegated to its proper role of

servant, to students and faculty, will the problems that beset Hopkins be successfully attacked. An ever increasing number of students, including some even from the ranks of the cynics,
are coming to that realization.
The beginnings of a class consciousness is
evident in the demands of the strikers. A governance system to include workers, with all members of the community to be represented on a
one man-one vote basis, is truly classless. In
ever growing numbers, students are shaking off
the notion, inculcated in them by our society,
that a man who works with his hands is inferior
and not capable of directing those actions which
affect him. Workers declared their solidarity with
students and a class division began to disappear.

Faculty Assembly Denunciations
On the other hand, the Faculty Assembly of Friday sharpened another division. Faculty denunciations of legal if "extra-channel" political moves
as "terrorism" and "gangsterism," reveal the
reactionary sentiment of many members of the
faculty. Allusions to feudal privileges,("My office
is my castle") show their disdain for equality
for all members within this community.
The strike was a successful demonstration of
the classic theory that if the governed take communal action, they can relieve the rulers of their
power. As with the entire human community, a
redefinition of morals is presently taking place.
Our heritage of laws to protect the rights of
property against human rights is being discarded
in favor of the rights of people to be protected
from those who have the power of property. People are dropping the legal definition of Johns Hopkins Incorporated in favor of Johns Hopkins...a
body of scholars, both novice and experienced.
As with all struggles between systems, the logic
of one may not be valid when applied to the other.
People committed to the old may find little sense
in the arguments of the new. That is when the
struggle begins.
"Radical" denotes the amount of change
advocated. "Militant" denotes the means for
effecting that change. While both are associated
with violence, neither necessarily imply it. The
movement at Hopkins restrained its violent urges
and the administration chose to yield to the forces of change before violence had to be resorted
to. Let us all hope that this is a precedent which
will not be broken.
